I just merged https://github.com/zulip/zulip/pull/11894, which redesigns the top navbar part of the Zulip UI to a new design that highlights stream descriptions. We can use this as the feedback thread. Huge thanks to @Yash RE for all the work that made this possible.

I'm about to deploy it here, so you'll be able to see it in action. I have a number of ideas for improvements, and we have a few issues we know about we're planning to fix forward, but I think it'll be easiest to do that in master where anyone can submit fixes easily via the normal PR process.

I just wish we could have moved faster with this :grimace:. I'm curious about bugs that arise from things we didn't even consider.
Again, cross browser testing heavily appreciated.

In the night theme, it feels like the text is too light.

image.png
I think that's just a bug -- we're using the same text color for day and night.

I'm also not sure the behavior is right if one modifies the search terms, without hitting enter to search, exits via escape, and then re-opens it. (Currently, this widget preserves what you last had there, rather than resetting it to the current view). I think resetting to the current view feels better, if you abandoned the search UI, you probably didn't mean for whatever you typed to stick around.
Yeah, I believe I mentioned that on my last comment on #11894, originally caught by Anders Kaseorg on #design > top navbar

another bug that I remembered after reading:

We should figure out a design for handling longer stream descriptions.

If you go to #feedback and mouse over the description you'll see that the tool tip looks messy since it is using rendered html. (The tool tip is how we're hoping to show the full description when text is being truncated).

Yeah, I think the design I actually want for that is a widget that pops down and shows an expanded description in more of a paragraph form on a persistent widget (so one can have and click links in it, etc.).
Yeah that sounds good.

The navbar piece looks clean visually.
Yeah, agreed re: that subscriber list idea; can you open an issue for that? Seems big enough to be an independent feature.
Regarding the design repeat, I agree with that as well; I think it makes sense to remove the stream part of recipient bars in narrows contained within a stream with this design.
That may also belong as an independent issue, since it's changing a different part of the UI.
I think probably we'll have ~5 threads of useful follow-up work to do here, and I encourage multiple folks to participate rather than expecting Yash to address everything.

image.png
I understand that we are more protective of vertical space than Slack, but I like how their search bar is always visible, and they compensate somewhat by just making the search input a bit shorter.

I also like how they somewhat downplay the counts by putting them on a separate line, which means the count is always in the same place (I concede that's a small thing), as well as the description, with the obvious cost of vertical real estate.

I wish we had something more like Slack's 3-line design:

  • search bar
  • stream name/topic name
  • count/description

And then we have things that are easy to discover for newbies. And then we reduce the problem to letting power users with short monitors re-claim some of the vertical real estate, which is a solvable problem.
I wish we had found some happy medium for description between the prior way (invisible and hard to discover) and the current way (in your face, wasting prime real estate).

I don't think having stream descriptions be always-visible is wasting prime real estate. The stream descriptions can be really valuable for new members in figuring out where to post something, and can be a useful reminder for existing users.
And I think our top most requested feature is the ability to pin content in that place in the UI for a stream precisely for this reason.
It's definitely prime real estate.

My main complaint about this design is it doesn't emphasize that you're in a single topic at the top of the screen ... but that is communicated clearly in the left sidebar, and it seems like one could retrain one's perception to use that to answer that question.

Or we could have a small visual hint in the center-navbar part of the screen to show that it's in a topic.
The bar for whether it's wasteful is the opportunity cost. People have reported wanting search there instead, as well as topics.
Well, for search, I think we could make the search click target be the whole area to the right of the subscriber count if we wanted to.
I guess it'd be a bit awkward with links in the stream description.

But Slack's 3-line design seems like a huge waste of space. I see why they have the search line be independent (to try to emphasize it's a global search, not a per-stream one) but I seem basically no benefit to their 2-line model for the rest of the block.

I don't think we actually need to communicate "which topic" you're in within that top navbar -- it's clear from the FRB element just below it. So one could imagine some adornment like having the text be a #design > | 14k | ... to make clear whether you're in a stream narrow or a topic narrow?

So, I think one question I'd like to ask at this point is whether we feel there's further fixes we want to make here before it ends up on zulipchat.com? Which is the point at which a much broader userbase will see this new design and start getting used to it.
I think there's a few interaction issues still (E.g. the way edits you make to the search box survive exiting via Esc) that we probably should fix in the immediate term.
But I want to refocus this thread on the goal of having an acceptable checkpoint place, instead of discussion of more complex things we can add that might be nicer.

Some polishing I’d suggest:

  • Agreed with previous comments about increasing the click target. (I know there’s a / keyboard shortcut but not everyone does.)
  • If I open search, type something dumb, close search, and open search again, it should forget the dumb thing and give me back the default query corresponding to my current view (so there’s a natural way to restore this default).
  • Perhaps the default query should be presented with a trailing space, so I can append to it with End some terms instead of End Space some terms.

Here's a fix:

--- static/styles/zulip.scss
+++ static/styles/zulip.scss
@@ -1495,12 +1495,11 @@ div.focused_table {

             &::before,
             &::after {
-                content: "";
+                content: "|";
                 position: absolute;
                 top: 25%;
-                width: 1px;
                 height: 50%;
-                background: hsl(0, 0%, 88%);
+                color: hsl(0, 0%, 88%);
                 @media (max-width: 500px) {
                     top: 10%;
                 }

We don't have an issue -- I don't think we've previously seriously considered moving the search bar.

There's two reasons one might not want to do that:

  • The right column hides in narrow windows -- so we'd need some fallback for having search still be accessible in those window shapes.
  • The right column isn't big enough to support what you actually entered as search -- which can be addressed by expanding it when clicked as yo mention.
